WRITING.TITLE: Can anyone remember previous exam fees (or membership fees) in #163;GBP?
WRITING.TEXT: Google is throwing a blank. I am surprised to see an 11% increase from #163;108 to #163;120 from 2018-2019 and I wondered what the fees were in the past for an F paper, I can't find previous years P-level exam fees. An 11% annual increase is phenomenal when the quality of service (in my experience within a specific CBE centre) has declined over the same time. I've seen candidates computers crash, answers inputted then lost when moving on to the next question and half asleep invigilators completely unaware of their surroundings. Are these price increases inline with other bodies? What is the purpose of them - a cynical cash grab? I can't see how their costs have increased by the same amount 11%!!! Crazy. I guess the top brass at ACCA are rolling in it.

WRITING.TITLE: ACCA smells a rat over forgery
WRITING.TEXT: "Arefin Raisa Khan, of Bangladesh, has the dubious honour of being the last part-qualified to be removed from the ACCA student register in 2019. Her sin? After becoming a student she failed F9 in June 2016, F7 in December 2017 and F6 in March 2017. She then claimed in January 2019 she had completed a BA degree with Anglia Ruskin University, and requested exemptions from papers F4 to F9. However, looking at the documents ACCA smelt a rat! Or, as ACCA put it, had "a suspicion regarding the authencity of the documents submitted". Anglia Ruskin confirmed the documents had been forged and related to a different student, who graduated in 2013. As well as being removed from the student register Khan was fined #163;6,600 in costs, reduced from #163;7,450." \- PQ Magazine The absolute doughnut.

I saw this from acca, in my understanding a cottage industry is a term used for small businesses at home. Ie an example would be if you had a little business making keyrings and selling them on the website etsy. It's a small business that enjoys the benefits of being at home and is never really going to take off into something massive. A fragmented industry is one where there are no single major players to move the industry in a certain direction. I. E., a non fragmented industry could be books, amazon are the market leader, they invented the kindle and started to move the industry towards e-books, a fragmented industry could be something like the food takeaway business, full of many different little players all doing different things but none of them are big enough to force the others into doing the same thing

I started ACCA late 20's with no real accounting knowledge or experience. The first three modules - AB, MA and FA - really bring you up to speed quickly. I don't think it's worth sitting AAT just to do ACCA immediately after. The caveat to this is that you need to have a certain level of qualification before starting at ACCA AB (F1). If you don't have them then you will have to start at the foundation level, and in this case it maybe worth while to pursue AAT first. [https://www.accaglobal.com/uk/en/qualifications/glance/foundation-level/overview.html](https://www.accaglobal.com/uk/en/qualifications/glance/foundation-level/overview.html) [https://www.accaglobal.com/uk/en/qualifications/glance.html](https://www.accaglobal.com/uk/en/qualifications/glance.html) Good luck!

I typically follow a similar approach for most of the ACCA exams. First I watch the videos on my chosen provider to get an idea of what the course is about. Whilst watching I type my own notes up. When I've finished that, I retype my notes into more of a brief version and I use the textbook to help refine my understanding. Once that's done I then start the exam kit and answer the questions on an "open book" basis, that is, I use the textbook to help me answer if I have tried and cannot do it by memory. Finally read the technical articles on the ACCA website and keep practising questions where possible. I try to sit the mock exams "closed book" i.e., not using the textbook to help. I've never sat a mock exam to time. I just try to go for thorough understanding. The night before the exam I rock myself a corner thinking why am I doing this to myself.

SBL being attempted towards the end is irrelevant, what matters is whether you can offer a business high quality advice using your business acumen, accounting knowledge and commercial awareness. This is what they are looking for in the exam. If you have failed SBL the likelihood is you are relying too much on the models outlined in the textbook and are not appropriately using the extracts given to you in the exam. I barely used a thing in the textbook and passed with a high mark just by putting ideas down and drawing upon experiences I had in the workplace. You should definitely continue with SBL and should do it alongside SBR.

I think having work experience helps, but I don't think you should put the brakes on your goals. It helped me because if a scenario came up I was able to think "what would my ex employer have done in this situation"

gt;So I currently have a full time job (not accountancy related) it is very flexible and I should be able to get time off for exams - so that part is not an issue. But I wondered how many hours per week roughly you would spend to study?- of course I know everyone is different but just wanted an average idea on whether it #8217;s feasible to do with a 37.5hr a week (not demanding) admin job. I'm UK too. If you think of an exam cycle as the 12 weeks between exams then I spend on average 2 hours a day for the first 6 weeks and up that to about 3-4 hours per day for the last 6 weeks. Some students use less time, I'm as thick as rocks so I like to take my time. #8203; gt;Second question is about the work experience, I know 36 months is needed, how did you get this? Did you find a job/placement before beginning the qualification? If so what and where do I need to search to find somewhere who will take me before beginning and who will ideally support me through gaining the qualification? Or have you found experience part way into studying, again how did this work? Or even after doing all exams? You can do this however you want but ideally you would like to start getting these months signed off as you proceed through your exams. If you do one exam a quarter and do not fail any then it is going to take you about 3 years to complete. You don't really want to spend another 3 years gaining the experience before you can call yourself chartered. There are two elements to it, the work experience and the PER objectives. Your line manager at your place of work can sign off the hours you have spent on an accounting/finance related role. For the PER, you need to achieve specific objectives which a chartered accountant signs off for you, they are essentially statements you write down to confirm that you have achieved a given objective, google it for more information. #8203; gt;Are there any exams I can not do without having work experience? Or is it possible to do them all and then find experience after? You can sit all exams without ever stepping foot in an accounting/finance role, but if you do it this way you don't have the opportunity to learn passively - i.e., things you may need to do in the exams may crop up as a daily task in your workplace. #8203; gt;My background is not in accounting, I have the necessary qualifications for joining, but my bachelors is in psychology and MA in criminology, so it #8217;s a big change to what I #8217;ve done previously. Do you know where I can find more specific details of the type of content before enrolling - so I can ensure it is definitely something I am capable of doing. You need to check out [https://www.accaglobal.com/uk/en/student/exam-support-resources.html](https://www.accaglobal.com/uk/en/student/exam-support-resources.html) and click the professional qualification, then each module and look at the syllabus. Be under no illusion, it's only a 50% score requirement to pass each module but the volume they expect you to learn and remember is huge, but as you are used to studying at a high level you should be accustomed to this already.

I passed on the first time, yes, there are no tips and tricks to studying any ACCA module, you simply need to learn the stuff. ACCA is a grind, there's no other way about it. WRITING.TEXT: Integrated report YE Mar 2019: [https://annualreport.accaglobal.com/mediaLibrary/other/english/ACCA-Integrated-Report-2019.pdf](https://annualreport.accaglobal.com/mediaLibrary/other/english/ACCA-Integrated-Report-2019.pdf) Consolidated Financial Statements and Corporate Governance Statement 2019: [https://annualreport.accaglobal.com/mediaLibrary/other/english/Consolidated-financial-statements-and-corporate-governance-statement-2019.pdf](https://annualreport.accaglobal.com/mediaLibrary/other/english/Consolidated-financial-statements-and-corporate-governance-statement-2019.pdf) For those who haven't the time to read it now, key takeaways: Members 219,031 in 2019 vs 208,549 in 2018, (and a fairly consistent 10k uplift per year since 2015) Students/Affiliates = 527,331 in 2019 vs 503,262 the year before #163;206m income (by comparison ACA had #163;114m and CIMA had #163;55m) * #163;97m of income came from us by way of fees and subscriptions, * #163;95m for qualifications/exams * #163;6m from *'regulation and discipline'* (!!!) #163;230m expenditure, #163;37m operating deficit. #163;191m on the balance sheet (though if you study ACCA you must call it the SOFP) One member of senior staff on #163;310,000-339,999 Found via [https://annualreport.accaglobal.com/about-acca](https://annualreport.accaglobal.com/about-acca)

You don't control your data if you have it saved onto the cloud. It's on somebody else's hard drive and you have no physical access to it and you are subject to the restrictions the hosting company place on your account. A large existing infrastructure could be that you have many different offices around the world for your business and the logistics of getting every one connected to your system could be expensive, cloud based is a more cost effective, less capital intensive way of doing it. If you don't want to sacrifice security then there's no chance you'd use cloud based That's my take on it anyway.

No, it can be completed anytime with no time restrictions. The ten year rule no longer exists, but it did back in 2009. If memory serves the only time limit rule now is that you must complete your P papers within 7 years of passing your first P paper. *edit, to clarify, the ten year rule was regarding time to complete the exams. There is no time limit to complete the three years work experience. They impose the time limit on the P papers to prevent the risk of a student taking many years to pass their P-papers, qualify as a new accountant and effectively have out of date knowledge as 'newly qualified'

Absolutely feel the same, it's been a really difficult cycle for me. Typically my pattern goes: * Sit exam A, * over the following six weeks start studying for exam B, * at the six week mark receive exam A score, if pass great, if fail make a study pattern to revise exam A around exam B * over the following six weeks revise for exam B * Repeat the process til all exams passed. I've found this process really helps with my pace, so I hit a point where I hit "peak performance" around the exam time. If I study for a period any longer and I start to forget things I did in the weeks prior, any quicker and I'm unprepared. I started in the second week of June but back then it was very uncertain as to whether or not we would be sitting September exams, this was demotivating. Well with the coronavirus shutdown my pacing has been well off. I'm doing SBR, there are that many rules to follow I just cannot remember them all (I'm going to sit APM too but I am completely unprepared for this, I'm only sitting it because I've paid for it). So I find myself in a similar position to you, momentum seems to be waning, stuff that I knew I now don't and I'm feeling pretty damn anxious if I'm to be honest. I just want this week to be over with. I think our problem is we have had to wait since March. Its tiring and the uncertainty we had as to whether we would sit these exams in September really takes the wind out of your sails. These are my last two exams, so no matter what I'll have to have a six week break between exam time and results day as I won't be able to start another, got to say I feel I need it, I've been at this for close to four years now. We're towards the end of the qualification and they say the last hurdles are the hardest to jump so try not to get stressed over it, try your best, I am sure you are prepared and when the time comes you will be in exam mode and I'm sure you'll pull it out of the bag.
I appreciate its not directly comparable, but do you think an ACCA module syllabus is similar, larger or smaller sized than that of a degree module?

Yes that's what I mean. In my experience I don't think the P paper syllabus is larger than the F paper syllabus in terms of new content, I just wondered how they compared to uni. My reason for asking is I have often thought, or wondered, that those who enjoy nine exemptions are at a way disadvantaged when starting ACCA papers due to how large the syllabus is, and that is reflected in the lower p-paper pass rate vs F papers. I started at AB, so I am used to doing it ACCA's way and I don't think that the step up to P papers has been too significant. Was just curious to see the perspective of a uni grad

My view on this and I have tried to keep it throughout my time studying the course is: In the days leading up to your exam do not worry, there's little you can do now, it's just last minute revision and cramming in as much as you can but ultimately whether you pass or fail is decided by what you did over the last few months. If you fail, you haven't lost anything, you just didn't gain it. If you pass, great, your process works! This helps keep me pretty relaxed for the most part
Guess it depends on what your run up is like, I tend to chill on the days leading up to an exam but then I've been studying every day for months
Don't forget your ID too!

You take the same docket for each exam, if you have another exam on another day they give it back to you at the end of your exam. It's only on your last exam they take it off you and keep it. They sign it each day you see and they put your desk number on. Yes bring your ID, a bottle of water without any labels or writing on, a few pens and your calculator

WRITING.TITLE: Statement from ACCA regarding exam disruptions
WRITING.TEXT: We are very sorry for the delays and disruptions experienced by some of our students sitting exams in the past two days. While the majority of students had a smooth experience in very busy exam sessions, we failed to reach our own high standards in some venues. Our initial reports show that issues were caused by problems with power supply at some centres and technology issues at others. We will continue to investigate what went wrong and make changes where we can in order to improve. Where possible, we will continue to offer students who have had exam sittings cancelled the chance to take the examination remotely within the next few days. We will do our best to ensure that students do not lose out professionally as a result of these difficulties and we are happy to refund their examination fees, if we are unable to reschedule the examination.

Do you get an opportunity to explain or represent yourself in the mitigating circumstances option. I wonder if you could say, for example I lost 25 minutes. So that's 25 minutes / 1.8 marks per minute = 13.8 marks I didn't get an opportunity to answer. Then they multiply that 13.8 marks by what you scored over the rest of the exam, say if you think you were running at 40%, and you gain 40% of marks you attempted that's an additional 5.5 marks they should give you. So in this example it'd be a fail, it's largely contingent on how you think you did. Just an idea. I wonder if that's how they handle stuff like that. If you think you did poorly, then take the resit
It shouldn't have to feel like a gamble, you just need to pick which feels best and right for you.
